NY JAZZ STORIES (cont)

Among the encounters that stuck with me from those days was meeting an older gentleman, Barney, who was managing a restaurant on Waverly I frequented as a student. 

Incredibly, I later found out it was Barney Josephson, founder of Caf√© Society.

NY JAZZ STORIES (cont)

Having learned jazz partly by listening to Voice of America on a short wave radio while hiding in Beirut bomb shelters, Greenwich Village was paradise.

I miss those days. 

And today, my heart breaks for the jazz community in this pandemic.

NY JAZZ STORIES (cont)

One of my favorite spots was Seventh Avenue South, started by the Brecker Brothers.

Some of the most brilliant musicians played there: John Scofield, Mike Mainieri, Mike Stern, the Breckers, etc. https://t.co/3MSfumiuRc

NY JAZZ STORIES (cont)

The Village Vanguard, Bradley's, Sweet Basil, and on and on.

I used to hang at @SmallsJazzClub when it first opened, and where I met my wife @leeladaou more than three decades later. https://t.co/Da3Ue3r488

NY JAZZ STORIES (cont)

An amazing experience was meeting Bob Thiele, who produced John Coltrane's A Love Supreme. It was surreal to talk to him about Trane's sessions.

There were great jazz clubs in every direction from Washington Square Park... https://t.co/LRRpfdlQeo

NY JAZZ STORIES (cont)

The Blue Note's jam sessions would start around 1am and go until 3 or 4 in the morning.

Curson was tough. I once got on stage and he called out Oleo at what seemed like a million beats per minute.

I flubbed and realized I had a lot more work to do.

NY JAZZ STORIES

When I settled in New York in the 80s and attended NYU, the Village had a vibrant jazz scene where you could see/hear living legends. I'd just escaped war in Lebanon and soaked up the music. The Blue Note had a great late-night jam session hosted by Ted Curson... https://t.co/4p8aJ82QLK
